Needs a back up and reatore from sd, not many people want to use or even know what adb is.

I use my phone as a second factor for my computer access so often times copying the token isn't necessary. Just a minor gripe.
Simple Fast and Lightweight

title: Opensource goodness
comment: Auto populated icons would be be a nice addition ;)

title: Works Great
comment: No excess permissions and work great

title: It just works.
comment: Pretty much the only good one-time password app right now. Sensibly designed, completely reliable.

title: Awesome!
comment: Great initiative by Redhat to develop a FOSS client like this - good layout and very stable. The one feature I would like to see would be the ability to export an (encrypted) backup of one's tokens to the local file system.

title: Excellent app
comment: It solved the problem that Google Authenticator always generated wrong code!
Caching the icons so I can remove the originals would make it perfect.
Beats the pants off Google Authenticator, and it's open source!
works but missing pin/password to unlock it.

title: Missing a few things
comment: Some form of backup implementation would be helpful. I'm jumping between far too many roms to have to setup everything each time. Dropbox och Drive backup would be nice, encrypted ofcourse.

title: Nice app
comment: Good alternative for the Google Authenticatior app
I don't know what to do

title: Great
comment: The only thing that would make this otherwise superb app better is Android Wear support.

title: Opensource, light, lacking
comment: Installed for it being opensource and from Red Hat. Used it happily for a few months,  then an update comes out that COPIES EVERY SINGLE SIX DIGIT OTP CODE TO THE CLIPBOARD and the most fun part is, THERE IS NO WAY (that I'm aware of) TO DISABLE CLIPBOARD INTEGRATION. One wonders what sort of attack would be possible with a large number of OTP codes skimmed from a user's clipboard over time. Also, the app lacks the ability to export individual tokens; so migrating to another app (or even backup) is a PITA.
An export to internal memory/SD card option would be nice.
Fast, clean, open
Great app

title: Fast, lightweight and open-source
comment: Fast, lightweight, open source. Totally ideal for the purpose. I wish more apps were like this.
Copy and paste does work automatically. The latest version even shows a popup indicating that the code was copied to the clipboard.

Does not work when system clock is not synchronized. I have set my clock 2 minutes ahead due to public transport. Update 20150113: Thanks for the Answer RedHat, I am aware that android has the native ntp feature. I was suspecting this was not a fault of your app. This app deserves 5 stars :-)

This is an inherent problem in the TOTP (Time-Based) token protocol. HOTP (Counter-Based) tokens do not have this problem. Are you able to use HOTP instead? Alternatively, you can synchronize your clock with an NTP server. This is a native feature of Android.

title: Fine.
comment: Generates TOTP codes to match perl Authen::OATH, which is what I need.

title: Great authenticator
comment: Better than google authenticator
Loses icons - wasted time getting and assigning icons just to have it revert later to no icons. Seems it only links icons but should copy them so independent of external files.
Great

title: Works on my oneplusone
comment: I could not get the Google authenticator working but this worked first time on my new phone.

title: Open source, light, missing easy backup
comment: After playing with it a bit the only downside is the backup. It needs a proper way to generate a local backup which I could copy to a computer with a  truecrypt volume using sftp. To backup you need to use the adb command on your computer. Connect your phone and run: adb backup -f freeotp.bak org.fedorahosted.freeotp  That will store the FreeOTP data to the file freeotp.bak. To restore this data, just run: adb restore freeotp.bak
adb backup should work. Did you try it?

title: Needs copy paste
comment: If I need to verify for mobile app

title: Many issues
comment: No export feature, change layouts without giving options to choose, and hotp implementation is broken.

I would very much like to understand the issues you are having. I'm not sure what you mean by "change layouts without giving options to choose." Our HOTP implementation is tested against the RFC test values and we have thousands of users using it without issue. Perhaps the token is being provisioned incorrectly? What do you want to export?

title: Open Source
comment: Liked it better before internet access was required - it's a security app after all - now major scrutiny is required each release (or a firewall app, ugh) - sorry non rooted laymen users, you're just gonna have to trust the devs with your second step. (e. g.  trust the home security guy with knowledge of where you keep your hidden key. Probably no big deal, but...)

Internet access it the only way to permit provisioning a token with an image. Every other major 2FA app out there requires internet permissions; but they aren't open source. What is important is not the requiring of internet permissions, but using them responsibly. With FreeOTP, if you don't trust us, you can just read the code.

title: Great piece of open source software
comment: Only issue I have is the QR scanner image is flipped 180 on my Nexus 6

title: Open & Auditable
comment: An open-source app is a must for security credentials. This one comes from the company I most trust to get it right.
Effective. Free. Open. Necessary.

title: Nice one
comment: Adding backup/restore will make it perfect.
A standard adb backup should work. Have you tried it?

title: Best OTP App
comment: Since Google Authenticator will not open anymore without crashing since I installed Lollipop I had to look for an alternative. I wish I had found this sooner. Better interface and slightly better physical security (by needing to tap an account before the code appears) than Google Authenticator, hands down. This app is going to be my only from now one.

title: Best Open Source OTP
comment: This is by far the best open source OTP app I've found. It's only downfall is that it lacks many of the features in the closed source apps such as backup/restore. However, 2 factor auth is all about being in control of my accounts, so I'm willing to forgo some of these highly desirable features in favor of open source.

title: Love it!
comment: No internet permission, small in size, opensouced, free! 5 stars, 2 thumbs up!

title: Best OTP Authenticator
comment: Better than the Google Authenticator which is going closed source, whereas this, from the folks who gave us Redhat Linux, is open source. Great looking interface as well. One of the most used apps on my mobile.

title: great otp tool
comment: a great open source otp tool! hoping to have a pin lock in the future.

title: Great app
comment: This works great. It is open source. Prefer this over Google Authenticator or Authy.  Only thing missing is being able to backup.

title: Perfect

title: Great but needs few more polish

title: Works great for all accounts I've used it with so far
comment: A perfect Free and Open Source drop-in replacement for the Google Authenticator app.
I dont know how to use it pls help
Better than Google auth
Works like a charm on my Nexus 5.

title: Great application
comment: Clean and simple UI. Much better than Google Authenticator. It would be nice to have some kind of exporting/importing feature.

title: Solid, flexible, stable
comment: Could use a bit more documentation, but overall clan and usable.

title: Great tool
comment: Great and easy-to-use tool that looks good. I like being able to add an image and the open source nature makes me trust it more than the Google TOTP app.

title: Simple and does the job
comment: Good alternative to Authenticator.

title: Fixed my problem
comment: At time of writing the Google Authenticator is not generating the correct code on Android 4.4.2. Using FreeOTP solved the issue.

title: Open source = trust
comment: I trust this open source app Red Hat far more than I trust closed source Google Authenticator from Google. Unlike Google Authenticator, it allows you to reorder your OTP entries and assign custom images to each entry. The only feature it lacks compared to Google Authenticator is the ability to move your codes to another device. Hopefully that gets added in a future version.

title: Great
comment: Really nice ui, better than the Google app.

title: Some known issues
comment: I have Nexus 4. On it I have the following issue: - I select a token to edit it - I change the icon using Gallery (Use once) - The icon is shown and saved - I close application and start it again  Expected: my selected image is displayed Actual: default image is displayed  After a conversation with project developers and testing on later version of Nexus it became apparent that the issue is with the image management library which looks like is fixed in the later versions. So do not blame the app for all the issues you see. 4 stars are well deserved!

title: Much better than anything else
comment: lt just works. Clean, simple.
Glad to see this now available.

title: G.Auth was good, but this is better, AND OPEN SOURCE
comment: Love the new v1.5 design. Took a while to find all the icons I needed online, but I'm good to go now. (Will be nice when all QR codes include image links.) The only thing I can imagine wanting to improve: the addition of a non-default setting to allow displaying all tokens all the time, like in GA (i.e., not requiring tap). Thank you Fedora, Red Hat.

title: Sync support
comment: Would love some kind of sync support (e.g. loading all my saved profiles from a WebDAV share or ownCloud)

title: Used to be 5 stars...
comment: UI is worse than it was in version 1.4 in many ways. Copy support has been removed, and despite the invasive new internet access permission the daft icons don't even work. (How is it supposed to know what icons to use, anyway?)

Copy to clipboard was not removed; it is now automatic.

I have explained the icon support and internet access permission here:
http://goo.gl/kPZXEc
Great update!

comment: Functional, but it could use some attention from someone who understands UX.

comment: What is there to say? It's a drop in replacement for Google Authenticator, except that it's prettier and has a few usability enhancements. I use it every day. Works flawlessly.

The barcode crash issues has been resolved in 1.5.

title: GAuth is great for *their* OTP, but for others...
comment: ...it kind of sucks because you can't rename profiles. FreeOTP lets you rename any profile so it means something to you, not something the provider thinks is meaningful. The price is right (free), as is the freedom. The interface is clean, and actually conforms better to HOLO than Google's offering (lol!). Will be using this exclusively from now on.
Does not suck.
Have a relatively in depth review of it, but it seems like Google only allows do many chars. So, it's on my Facebook and G+ pages, for anyone interested.

title: Good alternative to Authenticator app

comment: Looked for a good open-source replacement for Google Authenticator... this fits the bill perfectly and adds a nice ability to sort the items.

title: open source!
comment: google authenticator is not open source anymore, so let's all switch to freeOTP!!

title: Much better than Google Authenticator
comment: A better app, *and* open source. What's not to love?

title: Awesome and Simple
comment: Great Alternative and more over Open Source. Loved it.

title: Poor camera
comment: The camera could not capture the QR code, hence the app is unusable.

title: Awesome
comment: This app is solid. It's Free and Open Source Software, rather than the proprietary  Google Authenticator. Works with any TOTP implementation. Well done!

title: Great Google Auth Alternative
comment: After adding my 7th 2-factor account, I finally got pushed past the edge by getting so annoyed with not being able to reorder my accounts. FreeOTP is awesome, and definitely a great alternative that looks much better!  The one thing that I would really like is having a setting to always show all codes when I open the app. The extra tap gets a little frustrating. I understand its more secure, but not that useful to me, which is why I would like the setting.

title: Now better than google authenticator
comment: It was already prettier, and now it's flat-out better.

title: better alternative
comment: freeOTP over authenticator: smaller, less permissions, integrated barcode scanner, open source, manual detailed key entry possible...

title: Bravo !
comment: Awesome....works more efficiently compared to Google authenticator.

title: Awesome
comment: Unlike the Google Authenticator, FreeOTP supports custom periods.

title: Works Great
comment: I simply re-scanned my QR codes and converted from G-Authenticator in just a few minutes. Now I am running both until I am totally confident since it HAS to work when I need it. The Good news is you can move the order of the accounts around which you can't do in GA. The bad news is you can not rename accounts which you can do in GA. Overall it does the job and it is open sourced which gives me an extra level of trust.   **Added 2/15/14 - one complaint - I never noticed this on GA - is that it sucks my battery life on my Android phone if I don't remove it from my recently used list. I have 6 tokens that it is creating codes for, so maybe that takes a lot of processing power even when working in the background? Not a huge issue now that I know I need to do that each time but...
The battery eating bug has been fixed in v1.4.

title: the best!
comment: Better than Google Authenticator: it's open source and doesn't require internet access permission

title: Works well
comment: The interface is nice, and it's easy to use. The QR code reader is actually faster than Google's. The only thing I wish it had was a way to export a backup of the codes.

title: Great app
comment: The only thing missing is copy/paste for the codes, but I don't really use that anyway. Looks great on tablets too.  Best feature is that you can drag and reorder items.
Copy/paste was added in v1.4.

title: Excellent!
comment: I love having an open source alternative for Google's two factor authentication.  It seems to work great!

title: Freeing the code!
comment: I use this app every day! Love it. Also more attractive than GAuth. ;-)

title: Best of the bunch
comment: Just needs a copy to clipboard action and it'll be perfect. Perhaps the non sha1/6 digit options should be golden behind an "advanced"button to make setup more obvious for the 99.9% case, but hardly an essential change.
Copy to clipboard has been added. We're glad you think it is perfect now. :)

title: Doesn't work on S2
comment: Heya,  I have a galaxy S2 with cyanogenmod 10.2. When trying to scan a barcode the camera is upside down and doesn't auto focus / scan.  Any advice?  Thanks
We believe this issue to be fixed in the latest build (12). Please test it and let us know if you encounter any further difficulty.

title: Worked great on first try.
comment: After Google closed the source for their authenticator, I switched to Red Hat's FreeOTP. Setup took less than thirty seconds and everything worked as expected!

title: Easy
comment: The installation and usage of this application is so simple. The application itself is small and the only thing it reqires permissions to is the camera to scan QR codes. This application is a perfect replacement for the Google Authenticator.

title: Awesome
comment: Google closed sourced their OTP app. Red Hat stepped up and it works great.

title: Nice idea, doesn't work
comment: My phone it doesn't scan anything, the display is very dark, doesn't appear to AF and doesn't appear to work at all.  And it doesn't support my Nexus 7's front camera at all, wants me to type in everything.

https://fedorahosted.org/freeotp/ticket/8

The Nexus 7 (2012) camera problem should now be fixed (build 11; today). We also recently fixed a bug relating to auto-focus support. Please try the latest version.

Regarding the dark display, do you mean that the camera viewfinder is dark when attempting to scan? What device is this on?

title: Moto RAZR maxx HD
comment: Works great !

title: Awesome
comment: Great Free Software App! I've replaced Google Authenticator with this App now!

title: Perfect

Glad we could fix your problem!
Works well with a number of services such as drop box and github plus other commercial offerings

title: Know you are secure, with an Open Source OTP client
comment: Choose Open Source for your secure two-factor OTP authentication!  Google's previously-open Authenticator app is now a proprietary (closed source) solution. Thanks to Red Hat for helping keep authentication sources secure AND open!

title: Work as advertised
comment: It works as expected.  The only thing it needs to improved is it does not let you choose the QR scanner. It uses goggle as scanner, which is quite wordy and require extra steps if you just want it as QR scanner.
In version 1.3 we added native QR scanning support. No third party app is required now.
